column1: #FORMAT=WebAnno TSV 3.2
#T_SP=webanno.custom.Referent|entity|infstat
#T_RL=webanno.custom.Coref|type|BT_webanno.custom.Referent
#Text=Calculate Maturity Value
#Text=Maturity value is the amount payable to an investor at the end of a debt instrument ’s holding period ( maturity date ) .
#Text=For most bonds , the maturity value is the face amount of the bond .
#Text=For some certificates of deposit ( CD ) and other investments , all of the interest is paid at maturity .
#Text=If all of the interest is paid at maturity , each of the interest payments may be compounded .
#Text=To calculate the maturity value for these investments , the investor adds all of the compounding interest to the principal amount ( original investment ) .
#Text=Steps
#Text=Reviewing Debt Instruments
#Text=Go over the features of a bond .
#Text=A bond is issued to raise money for some purpose .
#Text=Corporations issue bonds to raise money to run the business .
#Text=Government entities , such as a city or state , may issue a bond to pay for a project .
#Text=A municipality may issue a bond to build a new public swimming pool , for example .
#Text=Every bond is issued with a specific face amount .
#Text=The face amount of the bond is the amount an investor receives at maturity .
#Text=The maturity date of a bond is the date that the issuer must repay the face amount .
#Text=In some cases , the face amount and all of the interest earned is repaid on the maturity date .
#Text=All of the details of the bond are listed on a bond certificate .
#Text=Today , bond certificates are issued in electronic form .
#Text=Investment professionals refer to this electronic format as book entry form .
#Text=The face amount and maturity date are listed on the book entry document , along with the interest rate .
#Text=If you buy a $ 10,000 6 % IBM corporate bond due in 10 years , for example , all of those details will be listed on the electronic bond certificate .
#Text=Consider the amount that you receive on the maturity date .
#Text=Most corporate bonds pay interest semi-annually .
#Text=At maturity , you receive the face amount of the bond .
#Text=Other debt instruments , such as certificates of deposit ( CDs ) , pay the face amount and all of the interest at maturity .
#Text=Another term for the face amount is the principal .
#Text=The formula to calculate interest earned is ( principal amount multiplied by interest rate multiplied by time period ) .
#Text=The annual interest for the IBM bond is ( $ 10,000 X 6 % X 1 year ) = $ 600 .
#Text=If all of the interest was paid at maturity , the first year ’s interest of $ 600 would not be paid until the end of 10 years .
#Text=In fact , each year ’s interest would be paid at the end of 10 years , along with the face amount ( principal ) .
#Text=Add in the impact of compounding .
#Text=Compounding means that the investor earns interest on both the face amount of the debt instrument , and any prior interest earned .
#Text=If your investment pays all of the interest at maturity , you will probably earn compounding interest on your past interest earnings .
#Text=The periodic rate is the rate of interest you earn for a particular time period , such as a day , week or month .
#Text=To calculate compounding interest , you need to determine the periodic rate .
#Text=Assume that your investment earns 12 % interest annually .
#Text=Your interest compounds monthly .
#Text=In this case , your periodic rate is ( 12 % / 12 months = 1 % ) .
#Text=To compound interest , you multiply the periodic rate by the face amount .
#Text=Determining The Maturity Value
#Text=Use the periodic rate to compute your interest earned .
#Text=Assume that you own a $ 1,000 12 % certificate of deposit that matures in 3 years .
#Text=Your CD pays all of the interest at maturity .
#Text=To compute the maturity value , you need to calculate all of your compounding interest .
#Text=Say that your CD compounds interest monthly .
#Text=You periodic rate is ( 12 % / 12 months = 1 % ) .
#Text=To keep it simple , assume that each month has 30 days .
#Text=Many investments , including corporate bonds , use a 360-day year to calculate interest .
#Text=Assume that January is the first month that you own the CD .
#Text=In month one , your interest is ( $ 1,000 ) X ( 1 % ) = $ 10 .
#Text=To calculate interest for February , you need to add the January interest to your principal amount .
#Text=Your new principal amount for February is ( $ 1,000 + $ 10 = $ 1,010 ) .
#Text=In February , you earn interest totaling ( $ 1,010 X 1 % = $ 10.10 ) .
#Text=You see that your February interest is higher than January ’s amount by 10 cents .
#Text=You earn additional interest because of compounding .
#Text=Each month , you add all of the prior interest to the original $ 1,000 principal amount .
#Text=The total is your new principal balance .
#Text=You use that balance to calculate interest for the next period ( a month , in this case ) .
#Text=Apply a formula to quickly calculate maturity value .
#Text=Rather than compute compounding interest manually , you can use a formula .
#Text=The maturity value formula is V = P x ( 1 + r)^n .
#Text=You see that V , P , r and n are variables in the formula .
#Text=V is the maturity value , P is the original principal amount , and n is the number of compounding intervals from the time of issue to maturity date .
#Text=The variable r represents that periodic interest rate .
#Text=For example , consider a 5-year , $ 10,000 CD compounded monthly .
#Text=The annual interest rate is 4.80 percent .
#Text=The periodic rate ( the r variable ) is ( .048 /12 months = .004 ) .
#Text=The number of compounding periods ( n ) is calculated by taking the number of years in the security and multiplying by the frequency of compounding .
#Text=In this case , your can compute the number of periods as ( 5 years X 12 months = 60 months ) .
#Text=The variable n equals 60 .
#Text=The maturity value , or V = $ 10,000 times ( 1 + .004)^60 .
#Text=The maturity value V works out to $ 12,706.41 .
#Text=Search for an online maturity value calculator .
#Text=Find an online calculator for maturity value using a search engine .
#Text=Make your search specific to the security you are valuing .
#Text=If you own a money market fund , for example , type in " money market fund maturity value calculator " .

column1: #Text=Search for a reputable site .
#Text=The quality and usability of each online calculator tool can vary greatly .
#Text=Use two different calculators to validate your results .
#Text=Input your information .
#Text=Enter the data from your investment or proposed investment into the calculator tool .
#Text=This will include the principal , annual rate of interest and the duration of the investment .
#Text=It may also include the frequency of compounding for the investment .
#Text=Check the result .
#Text=Make sure that the maturity value makes sense .
#Text=To verify that the maturity date is reasonable it probably makes sense to confirm the result in another online tool .
#Text=Quick Summary
